title.native: 学園黙示録HIGHSCHOOL OF THE DEAD
title.romaji: Gakuen Mokushiroku: HIGHSCHOOL OF THE DEAD

description:
The lockers are splattered with blood, the student bodies are piling up and that's not mystery meat they're eating in the cafeteria… it's the faculty! And that's just the start of the worst day of school ever when a nightmarish virus is unleashed, turning humans into flesh eating zombies and converting Fujimi High School into a literal hell on Earth. Now it's a crash course in survival, and the only test or skill that matters is the ability to keep moving, breathing and fighting. Because if nerds, jocks and the surviving staff can't find a way to work together to escape this carnal house of education, they're all going to end up on the menu. And that's assuming there's anyplace safe left to escape to.

(Source: Sentai Filmworks)
synonyms: High School of the Dead: Apocalipsis en el Instituto

tags.name: Zombie
tags.description: Prominently features reanimated corpses which often prey on live humans and turn them into zombies.

tags.name: Survival
tags.description: Centers around the struggle to live in spite of extreme obstacles.

tags.name: Pandemic
tags.description: Prominently features a disease prevalent over a whole country or the world.

tags.name: Gore
tags.description: Prominently features graphic bloodshed and violence.

tags.name: Male Protagonist
tags.description: Main character is male.

tags.name: Conspiracy
tags.description: Contains one or more factions controlling or attempting to control the world from the shadows.

tags.name: Ensemble Cast
tags.description: Features a large cast of characters with (almost) equal screen time and importance to the plot.

tags.name: Body Horror
tags.description: Features characters who undergo horrific transformations or disfigurement, often to their own detriment.

tags.name: Nudity
tags.description: Features a character wearing no clothing or exposing intimate body parts.

tags.name: Guns
tags.description: Prominently features the use of guns in combat.

tags.name: Female Harem
tags.description: Main cast features the protagonist plus several female characters who are romantically interested in them.

tags.name: Primarily Teen Cast
tags.description: Main cast is mostly composed of teen characters.

tags.name: Large Breasts
tags.description: Features a character with larger-than-average breasts.

tags.name: Love Triangle
tags.description: Centered around romantic feelings between more than two people. Includes all love polygons.

tags.name: Swordplay
tags.description: Prominently features the use of swords in combat.

tags.name: Ojou-sama
tags.description: Features a wealthy, high-class, oftentimes stuck up and demanding female character.

tags.name: Politics
tags.description: Centers around politics, politicians, or government activities.

tags.name: Tsundere
tags.description: Prominently features a character who acts cold and hostile in order to mask warmer emotions.

tags.name: Heterosexual
tags.description: Prominently features a romance between a man and a woman, not inherently sexual.

tags.name: School
tags.description: Partly or completely set in a primary or secondary educational institution.

tags.name: Military
tags.description: Centered around the life and activities of military personnel.

tags.name: Shounen
tags.description: Target demographic is teenage and young adult males.

tags.name: Assassins
tags.description: Centers around characters who murder people as a profession.

tags.name: Unrequited Love
tags.description: One or more characters are experiencing an unrequited love that may or may not be reciprocated.

tags.name: Police
tags.description: Centers around the life and activities of law enforcement officers.

tags.name: Suicide
tags.description: The act or an instance of taking or attempting to take one's own life voluntarily and intentionally.

tags.name: Animals
tags.description: Prominently features animal characters in a leading role.

tags.name: Rape
tags.description: Features non-consensual sexual penetration.

tags.name: Female Protagonist
tags.description: Main character is female.

node.description:
Yousuke Kuroda is a Japanese screenwriter. He is affiliated with Studio Orphee and serves as the inside director (board of directors member).

Kuroda is a prolific writer in the anime industry. Having authored and scripted numerous anime series. Including several original productions. Some of the most notable are Infinite Ryvius, Scryed, Please☆Teacher!, Mobile Suit Gundam 00, and Waiting in the Summer.

In 2003, he won the Individual Award at the 8th Animation Kobe event.
Daisuke Satou was a Japanese board game designer, novelist, and manga writer. He died on March 22, 2017 from ischaemic heart disease.

__Doujin Circle:__ GEBOKUDOU (下僕堂), DIGITAL ACCEL WORKS (デジタルアクセルワークス). 

[Website](http://www.ghost-d.com/ssss/) | [Twitter](https://twitter.com/ss_shouji)

Early in his career, Shouji Satou was the former assistant of mangaka [Koshi Rikudo](https://anilist.co/staff/99237/Koshi-Rikudo).

[Twitter](https://twitter.com/i/user/265406784) | [Facebook](https://www.facebook.com/tetsuro.araki.75)

Joined [MADHOUSE](https://anilist.co/studio/11/MADHOUSE) in 1999 as a production manager, making his storyboard and episode director debut with [Galaxy Angel](https://anilist.co/anime/383/) just two years later. In 2005, he made his proper directorial debut with [Otogi-juushi Akazukin](https://anilist.co/anime/402/), a single-episode OVA which was aimed more at figure collectors than at anime fans. Its popularity birthed the full-length series and manga which both came out afterwards.

In 2006, Araki helmed his first big project with [Death Note](https://anilist.co/anime/1535/), which gained him international praise. He has since gone on to direct numerous series from originals such as [Guilty Crown](https://anilist.co/anime/10793/) and [Kabaneri of the Iron Fortress](https://anilist.co/anime/21196/), to the massively successful adaptation of [Attack on Titan](https://anilist.co/anime/16498/), whose production Araki left with the studio change.

He's been close friends with [Takayuki Hirao](https://anilist.co/staff/102247/) since their days at [MADHOUSE](https://anilist.co/studio/11/). The two have frequently collaborated on numerous projects.

Married to [Aya Hida](https://anilist.co/staff/144626/).

Freelance, however primarily works at [WIT Studio](https://anilist.co/studio/858/) with Animation Producer [Kazuki Yamanaka](https://anilist.co/staff/196459/).
[Wiki (jp)](https://ja.wikipedia.org/wiki/たなかかずや)

[Profile (MONACA)](https://monaca.jp/member/kosaki) | [Twitter](https://twitter.com/MONACA_kosaki)

A Japanese composer and arranger. He joined NAMCO as a soundtrack composer in 1999, and then he joined MONACA Inc. as a music designer in 2004.

Soundtracks he has worked on credited as MONACA: 
- Star Driver: Kagayaki no Takuto (with Keigo Hoashi and Ryuichi Takada) 
- Hourou Musuko (with Keigo Hoashi and Keiichi Okabe) 
- A-Channel (with Kakeru Ishihama, Ryuichi Takada, Keigo Hoashi)

[Profile (MONACA)](https://monaca.jp/member/kosaki) | [Twitter](https://twitter.com/MONACA_kosaki)

A Japanese composer and arranger. He joined NAMCO as a soundtrack composer in 1999, and then he joined MONACA Inc. as a music designer in 2004.

Soundtracks he has worked on credited as MONACA: 
- Star Driver: Kagayaki no Takuto (with Keigo Hoashi and Ryuichi Takada) 
- Hourou Musuko (with Keigo Hoashi and Keiichi Okabe) 
- A-Channel (with Kakeru Ishihama, Ryuichi Takada, Keigo Hoashi)
Senior vocalist for the music group I'VE SOUND.

[Twitter](https://twitter.com/i/user/589238508)

Originating from [Artland](https://anilist.co/studio/8/), currently affiliated with [CloverWorks](https://anilist.co/studio/6222/CloverWorks).

John Ledford is an entrepreneur and leader in the North American anime industry. In 1992, he founded A.D. Vision (ADV), paving the way for other businesses and the exponential growth anime has had within North America. With ADV's success, Ledford turned his sights to making the imaginative world of anime even more accessible with Anime Network's founding, North America’s first cable TV network dedicated to anime. He later partnered with Kadokawa Publishing and began Newtype USA with translated Japanese content and exclusive U.S. material related to all things anime, manga, and model reviews. This endeavor expanded into ADV Manga, which obtained licensing and publishing rights for hundreds of Japanese manga and Korean manhwa.

In 2008, Ledford founded a new anime-focused company called Sentai Filmworks (Sentai). Since its founding, Sentai provides thousands of hours of content across traditional and digital platforms. Sentai’s dedication to bringing captivating stories, including acclaimed titles such as Grave of the Fireflies, Ninja Scroll, and High School of the Dead to audiences, is ongoing.

Ledford’s most recent success is with the 2017 founding of the streaming service HIDIVE. Since launching, HIDIVE is now available via a web browser, mobile devices, gaming platforms, and more. HIDIVE offers new simulcasts every season, an ever-growing collection of dubs, and exclusive titles. The service features DUBCAST SM editions, early access local-language dubs of simulcasts directly produced by HIDIVE, as early as two weeks after the original Japanese broadcast.

For nearly thirty years now, Ledford continues his goal to further the expansion of anime and the Japanese culture as a whole.
Takafumi Wada is a Japanese Composer.

[Profile](http://nbcuni-music.com/maon/profile/) | [Blog](http://ameblo.jp/kurosakimaon) | [Twitter](http://twitter.com/kurosakimaon) | [Youtube](http://www.youtube.com/user/maongue) 

Maon Kurosaki was a Japanese singer and songwriter signed to NBCUniversal Entertainment Japan. After being discovered while working as a performer in Akihabara, Tokyo, she made her major debut in 2010, performing ending themes to the anime television series Highschool of the Dead. She released her debut album H.O.T.D. in September 2010, which features the ending themes from Highschool of the Dead. Her first two singles were used as ending themes to the anime television series A Certain Magical Index II.

Kurosaki's music is influenced by her love of anime and lolita fashion. Her songs have been featured in various anime series such as Jormungand, Tokyo Ravens, and The Fruit of Grisaia. She has collaborated with artists such as Mami Kawada, Kotoko, and Trustrick for her music releases. She performed twice at Anime Expo 2011 in Los Angeles, California, and is a regular performer at Japanese anime events such as LisAni, Animelo Summer Live, and Animax Musix. She has also appeared at Anime Festival Asia, Bangkok Comic Con, and CharaExpo. From 2011 to 2016, she was singer of the synthpop band [ALTIMA](https://anilist.co/staff/109511/), together with Motsu of the band Move.
[Instagram](https://www.instagram.com/ste7en_foster/) | [Facebook](https://www.facebook.com/foster.steven)
[Instagram](https://www.instagram.com/ste7en_foster/) | [Facebook](https://www.facebook.com/foster.steven)

__[Profile (MONACA)](http://www.monaca.jp/staff/takada.html)__

__Ryuuichi Takada__ is a Japanese composer, arranger and member of music unit MONACA. He mainly composes and arranges for videogames, having worked on the soundtracks for Soul Calibur, Tekken, Katamari Damacy, and The iDOLM@STER.

__[Profile (MONACA)](http://www.monaca.jp/staff/takada.html)__

__Ryuuichi Takada__ is a Japanese composer, arranger and member of music unit MONACA. He mainly composes and arranges for videogames, having worked on the soundtracks for Soul Calibur, Tekken, Katamari Damacy, and The iDOLM@STER.

node.description:
__[Website](https://kisidakyoudan.com/)__ | __[Website (Warner Bros Japan)](https://whv-amusic.com/kisidakyoudan/)__ | __[Twitter](https://twitter.com/kisida_info)__ | __[Facebook](https://www.facebook.com/kisidakyoudan/)__ | __[YouTube](https://www.youtube.com/channel/UCl7OsED7y9eavZJbTGnK0xg/videos)__ | __[Instagram](https://www.instagram.com/kisidakyodan/)__ | __[Spotify](https://open.spotify.com/artist/1zPnpAM7fGFr7pl8OSNvak?si=ZPjWJdhFSR-cVEZHiynphQ)__ | __[Spotify (kishidakyoudan)](https://open.spotify.com/artist/0V8dBE2G0SkXl7GoWnflOk?si=95X396W9RLCizLym_eGy2A)__

__Introduction:__
Kishida Kyoudan & The Akeboshi Rockets is a Japanese rock band under record label Warner Bros Home Entertainment (2013–), having previously been under Geneon Universal (2010–2011). The band initially formed as a one-man unit under the name Kishida Kyoudan (stylized as kishidakyoudan) in 2004. The band made its independent debut in 2005 with the album SUPERNOVA, while still continuing to release the next four albums under the name Kishida Kyoudan, before changing their name to Kishida Kyoudan & The Akeboshi Rockets in 2007.

__Biography:__
The band began in 2004 as a one-man unit consisting of the musician Kishida, who dedicated his time to cover songs from various series. One prominent series which he covered a lot was the Touhou Project, in addition to  other video games by Japanese visual novel studio [Key](http://key.visualarts.gr.jp/). He would go on to release a CD in 2005 featuring original songs and covers of various songs from the Type-Moon games and the Touhou Project, which he featured for sale at the Winter Comiket in the same year.

In 2007, Kishida received a request to perform at the Touhou live event "Flowering Night", he accepted and gathered various members regardless of personality or experience to form the unit "Kishida Kyoudan & The Akeboshi Rockets". They originally planned to disband after performing at the event, but due to unexpected positive feedback from the audience they decided to continue as a band. Later, in the same year, the vocalist ichigo also joined the band.

The band made their major debut in July 2010 through NBCUniversal Entertainment (who at the time were known as Geneon Universal), performing the single titled "HIGHSCHOOL OF THE DEAD" in the anime with the same name _[HIGHSCHOOL OF THE DEAD](https://anilist.co/anime/8074/Gakuen-Mokushiroku-HIGHSCHOOL-OF-THE-DEAD/)_. The full single was released a month later on August 18, 2010, which was their first single release as Kishida Kyoudan & The Akeboshi Rockets, which was a whole three years after officially starting band activities. Additionally their first album titled "POPSENSE" was released a year later on June 22, 2011, spanning a total of eleven tracks.

Skipping three years ahead to 2013, the band would make its reappearance in anime performing the single titled "STRIKE THE BLOOD" to the show with the same name _[STRIKE THE BLOOD](https://anilist.co/anime/18277/Strike-the-Blood/)_, while on December 24, 2014 they would release their second album titled "hack/SLASH", which also spanned a total of eleven tracks.

In 2015, on July 5, and in the following year 2016, on January 9, the band would make two consecutive appearances in the anime _[GATE](https://anilist.co/anime/20994/Gate-Jieitai-Kanochi-nite-Kaku-Tatakaeri/)_, and its sequel _[GATE II](https://anilist.co/anime/21364/Gate-Jieitai-Kanochi-nite-Kaku-Tatakaeri-2/)_, performing the singles "GATE (Sore wa Akatsuki no You ni)" and  "GATE II (Sekai o Koete)". The full versions of the singles released on July 29, 2015 and on January 27, 2016 respectively. They would, in addition, go on to make two more appearances in anime in 2016, with the first one being in _[Alderamin on the Sky](https://anilist.co/anime/21410/Nejimaki-Seirei-Senki-Tenkyou-no-Alderamin/)_ on July 9, performing the single "Tenkyou no Alderamin" and on November 23, performing the single "BLOOD ON THE EDGE", in the show _[Strike the Blood II](https://anilist.co/anime/21815/Strike-the-Blood-II/)_.

__Members:__
- [Kishida](https://anilist.co/staff/153287/Kishida) (岸田) – bassist, guitarist, in-charge of lyrics, composition and arrangement
- [ichigo](https://anilist.co/staff/257500/Ichigo) – vocalist
- [Hayapi](https://twitter.com/hayapi_san_V3) (はやぴ～) – lead guitarist
- [Micchan](https://twitter.com/MI_CYAN_GOGO) (みっちゃん) – drummer

__Support Members:__
- [T-tsu](https://twitter.com/t_tsu8) (てっ), also known as T-tsu-chan (てっちゃん) – guitarist

Former adult game scenario writer. He is a creator of cult classic Shizuku, Kizuato and To Heart.

[Twitter](https://twitter.com/t_takahasi)

[Wiki (jp)](https://ja.wikipedia.org/wiki/宮繁之)

Originating from [Studio Deen](https://anilist.co/studio/37/).

[Twitter](https://x.com/hira0takayuk1)

He graduated from Osaka's Designer College and started his career at [Madhouse](https://anilist.co/studio/11/MADHOUSE) as a production assistant, later making the transition to storyboarder and episode director with [Texhnolyze](https://anilist.co/anime/26/). During his time at Madhouse he served as Assistant Director to [Satoshi Kon](https://anilist.co/staff/99580/Satoshi-Kon) on [Paranoia Agent](https://anilist.co/anime/323/Paranoia-Agent/) and was greatly influenced by him, regarding him as his mentor. Shortly after leaving Madhouse he joined [Ufotable](https://anilist.co/studio/43/ufotable), where he worked for several years and made his proper directorial debut with [Kara no Kyoukai 5](https://anilist.co/anime/4282/). 

He left Ufotable in 2016 and he's been freelance since, returning to the company only to direct the opening for the video game Shin Megami Tensei: Strange Journey. 

Him and [Tetsurou Araki](https://anilist.co/staff/100088/) are really close friends since their days at Madhouse. They run a column called *Bariuta no ai wo shiritai!!* published in the Animage monthly magazine. 

He is married to color designer [Emi Chiba](https://anilist.co/staff/103075/).
[Twitter](https://twitter.com/suya_suya2016)

Designer, director, and animator originally from [MADHOUSE](https://anilist.co/studio/11). He made his directorial debut in 2018 with [Megalo Box](https://anilist.co/anime/100298). Frequently works with [Tetsurou Araki](https://anilist.co/staff/100088).

Designer, director, and animator originally from [MADHOUSE](https://anilist.co/studio/11). He made his directorial debut in 2018 with [Megalo Box](https://anilist.co/anime/100298). Frequently works with [Tetsurou Araki](https://anilist.co/staff/100088).
